of bright lines (a)(b)(c),(d),(e),(f),(g)(h),
which are to be ranged into two different 
sets (a)(b)(c)(d) and (e)(f),(g)(h). It is a 
curious fact that all these different types 
either fully developed or indicated only,
are represented <s>by<\s> in the flame of cyanogen,
if fed with <s>air<\s> oxygen, while in all other cases,
we examined, there are represented, either 
a single type or two types or even three <a>,<\s>
namely 1/ the third type alone, 2 the first type 
with the second set of groups, 3 the third 
type with one set of groups, ((a)(b)(c)(d)) 4 the same 
type with the other set ((e),(g)), 5 the second and third 
type with the first set of groups. There 
is no doubt that the different types correspond 
to different degrees of temperature: the 
temperature being lowest when the bands 
are principally developed; lower in the 
case of the second set of groups than in 
the case of the first; lower in the case of 
the shadowed large fields than in the case 
where the characteristic groups appear 
simultaneously.
56. In the present state of the question we 
are not fully able to explain the various 
types of spectra of carbon. It is only 
proved that all spectra which we referred 
to carbonic vapour do not contain any 
bright line belonging to another elemen 
tary gas. Either the well known spectra of 
foreign admixed gases, of nitrogen, oxygen 
hydrogen, for instance, do not appear at all
